data.name: Computer Science Club
data.description: The Computer Science Club exists to promote knowledge of and interest in computer science and to provide a space for those interested in computer science to connect. It maintains an office where members gather, offers a library of computer science books, provides computer accounts on various machines, and regularly hosts computing-related events such as talks, tutorials, and demonstrations.

data.name: Double Degree Club
data.description: The Double Degree Club (DDC) is an official, UW and WLU registered, student-run organization that enhances the experience of Double Degree students. Supported by its members, the club hosts social events, networking and mentorship opportunities, and provides academic resources. It also works closely with administration at both universities to strengthen the presence and professional development of its members.

data.name: Statistics Club
data.description: The University of Waterloo’s Statistics Club is the official student-run club serving the university’s statistics undergraduates. It is dedicated to uniting the statistics community by offering a friendly and welcoming environment and by supplying resources that support the academic pursuit of Statistics.

data.name: Actuarial Sciences Club
data.description: The UW ActSci Club is the official student organization for actuarial science undergraduates. It brings together students pursuing actuarial careers to network, learn, and improve their UW experience. The club hosts weekly social and informational events, lends actuarial exam study manuals, runs a mentorship program, and serves as a hub for actuarial news and events from its office in M3 1003.

data.name: Financial Analysis or Risk Management Student Association
data.description: FARMSA is a non-profit student club open to all Math students, not just those in the Math/FARM program. Its goals are to encourage academic pursuits related to Math/FARM, provide academic and professional services, improve cohesiveness among Math/FARM students, and build and promote the reputation and quality of the Math/FARM program.

data.name: Pure Math, Applied Math and Combinatorics & Optimization Club
data.description: The Pure Math Club is a non-profit student club open to anyone interested in various areas of mathematics. It organizes academic and social events such as professor and student talks, math contests, and social gatherings at the beginning, middle, and end of terms. Its office in MC 3033 provides workspace, reference books, and resources like a blackboard, whiteboard, and computer.

data.name: Data Science Club
data.description: The Data Science Club supports the University of Waterloo in producing top data scientists. It provides a platform for discussing Data Science topics and events and creates a supportive network for learning and job searches.

data.name: MathSoc Cartoons
data.description: MathSoc Cartoons is a student-run comic series that explains undergraduate math and computer science concepts. All comics are available online and through the series’ Instagram and Facebook pages.

data.name: Math Ambassadors
data.description: Math Ambassadors is a volunteer program where students share their pride, experience, and knowledge about the Faculty of Mathematics with prospective students and their families while developing campus knowledge and leadership skills.

data.name: Math Endowment Fund
data.description: The Mathematics Endowment Fund (MEF) is an income-generating fund that finances projects benefiting undergraduate math students at the University of Waterloo.

data.name: Math Orientation
data.description: Math Orientation supports incoming and current students in finding a community to succeed academically and socially, fostering Faculty and School pride whether students participate on campus or remotely.

data.name: mathNEWS
data.description: mathNEWS is Waterloo’s bastion of erudite thought, providing a platform for student-created content and commentary.

data.name: Women in Math
data.description: The Women in Mathematics (WiM) committee encourages and advocates for women interested in studying mathematics or pursuing careers in the field. It addresses cultural and institutional barriers and strives for gender diversity within mathematics.

data.name: Women in Computer Science
data.description: Women in Computer Science (WiCS) is dedicated to promoting and supporting women studying computer science and pursuing careers in computing.

data.name: Mathematics Graduation Committee
data.description: The UW Mathematics Graduation Committee organizes events for graduating Mathematics students, including the Grad Ball and Yearbook production, and can be contacted for involvement or inquiries.

data.name: Waterloo Engineering Endowment Fund
data.description: Founded in 1990 by engineering students Avi Belinsky and John Vellinga, the Waterloo Engineering Endowment Fund (WEEF) exists to continuously improve the educational environment for undergraduate engineering students at the University of Waterloo. Donations are invested; only the interest is spent each year on laboratory equipment, student projects, computer upgrades, and academic tools, ensuring the principal grows and provides long-term support—“The Gift That Keeps On Giving.” Funding comes from student donations, Employer Matching Contributions, and engineering alumni pledges.

data.name: The Iron Warrior
data.description: The Iron Warrior is the official newspaper of the Waterloo Engineering Society. Produced by members of the Society, it serves as a forum for thought-provoking and informative articles, opinions, and news from the Society, the Faculty of Engineering, and the wider university community.

data.name: UWaterloo EngiQueers
data.description: UWaterloo EngiQueers is the campus chapter of the not-for-profit EngiQueers Canada. The group connects LGBTQ+ engineering students, offering a welcoming, drop-in environment with weekly informal meetings that typically feature queer-themed movies, discussions, and board games.

data.name: Women In Engineering
data.description: Women In Engineering (WiE) has been part of the University of Waterloo since 1992. Its mission is to foster an inclusive, intersectional community for engineering students of all genders, with a focus on supporting and encouraging women, including trans and non-binary students, to pursue and thrive in engineering careers. WiE organizes social events every academic term.

data.name: National Society of Black Engineers
data.description: NSBE UW is the University of Waterloo collegiate chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers. Its goal is to build an active community that supports the academic and professional success of Black engineering students. The chapter hosts speaker series with alumni, organizes 'Black Study Hall' sessions, and is developing initiatives like a member mentorship program to enhance networking, academic performance, and overall university experience.

data.name: American Indian Science and Engineering Society
data.description: The University of Waterloo chapter of the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) welcomes Indigenous, Métis, and Inuit students in STEM fields. It aims to create a supportive community that fosters academic and professional growth. In Fall 2023, the chapter launched a rocketry team to compete in the First Nations Launch (FNL) competition.

data.name: Engineering Student Societies' Council of Ontario
data.description: The Engineering Student Societies' Council of Ontario (ESSCO) represents engineering societies from 16 universities across Ontario, serving as the link between engineering students, professional associations, academia, and government. Since 1987, ESSCO has worked to promote unity, continuity, and visibility among Ontario engineering students.

data.name: Canadian Federation of Engineering Students
data.description: The Canadian Federation of Engineering Students (CFES) is a national, bilingual organization representing around 81,000 engineering students across Canada. CFES provides opportunities that support a comprehensive education, represents and promotes Canadian undergraduate engineering students nationally and internationally, and facilitates the exchange of information and activities to improve the quality and scope of engineering education and experience.
